options.content:
# Statement statistics

## Labels
`datname` — name of the database

# Statement execution time statistics

## Metrics
`pg_stat_statements_mean_execution_time` — mean time of query execution (per database)

`pg_stat_statements_stddev_execution_time` — deviation from mean for query execution times (per database)

It is useful to plot mean as line and stddev as error band

# Total number of calls

## Metrics
`pg_stat_statements_total_calls` — total number of calls to database. Note: Postgres records information only for limited number of queries.

# Database statistics

## Labels
`datname` — database name

# Databse Size

## Metrics
`pg_database_size` — size of each database in bytes
# Table statistics

# pg_table_metrics — active database tables information

## Metrics
`pg_table_size` — table size in bytes

## Labels
`table_name` — name of the table
# Statistics for all requests

# Request metrics

## Metrics
`pg_duration_seconds_sum` — total number of seconds spent executing requests
# Database-wide statistics

# Commits and rollbacks
## Metrics

`pg_requests_total` — number of transactions that have been committed

`pg_errors_total` — number of transactions that have been rolled back

# Rows modified

## Metrics

`pg_inserts_total` — number of rows that have been inserted

`pg_updates_total` — number of rows that have been updated

`pg_deletes_total` — number of rows that have been deleted

# Fetches and Returns

## Metrics
`pg_rows_returned` — number of rows returned
- For table: number of rows scanned. For table it is the number of rows scanned using seq scan
- For index: number of index entries returned by index access

`pg_rows_fetched` — number of rows fetched
- For table: number of rows fetched under control of bitmap indexscans
- For index: number of rows fetched under control of simple indexscan

If `pg_rows_fetches` significantly larger than `pg_rows_returned`, it means that there are many full table scans.

# Block reads
## Metrics
`pg_blks_hit` — number of blocks found in Postgres buffer cache, read was not neccessary

`pg_blks_read` — number of blocks read from disk

# Backends

## Labels:
`backend` — state of the backend

# Number of backends by state

## Metrics
`pg_activity_count` — number of backends by state
# Postgres Configuration

# Maximum number of connections

## Metrics
`pg_activity_max` — max connections allowed to server

# Per-table index and sequential scans

## Labels
`table_name` — name of the table

# Table index scans

## Metrics
`pg_idx_scan` — number of index scans initiated on the table

## Labels
`table_name` — name of the table on which scan was initiated

# Table sequential scans

## Metrics
`pg_seq_scan` — number of sequential scans initiated on the Table

# Replication metrics

## Labels:
`pid` — WAL sender PID

`client_addr` — IP of client connected to WAL sender. Null if using UDS on same machine.

`user` — user connected to the WAL sender

`application_name` — application connected to the WAL sender

`state` — WAL sender state

# Replica Lag in bytes

## Metrics
`pg_replication_pending_lag_bytes` — Number of bytes standby lags behind primary in pending phase

`pg_replication_write_lag_bytes` — Number of bytes standby lags behind primary in write phase

`pg_replication_flush_lag_bytes` — Number of bytes standby lags behind primary in flush phase

`pg_replication_replay_lag_bytes` — Number of bytes standby lags behind primary in replay phase

`pg_replication_total_lag_bytes` — Number of bytes standby lags behind primary in total

# Replica lag in seconds

## Metrics
`pg_replication_write_lag_seconds` — Number of seconds standby lags behind primary in write phase

`pg_replication_flush_lag_seconds` — Number of seconds standby lags behind primary in flush phase

`pg_replication_replay_lag_seconds` — Number of seconds standby lags behind primary in replay phase

`pg_replication_total_lag_seconds` — Number of seconds standby lags behind primary in total
